correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: ADAMS, Samuel, American statesman, born at Boston, Sept. 27, 1722, was second cousin to John Adams. He studied at Harvard, but, owing to his father’s misfortunes in business in connection with a banking speculation,—the “manufactory scheme,”—he had to leave before completing his course, and to relinquish his intention of becoming a Congregational clergyman. He received his degree, however, and it is worthy of note, as showing the tendency of his political opinions, that his thesis was a defence of the affirmative reply to the question, “Whether it be lawful to resist the supreme magistrate, if the commonwealth cannot otherwise be preserved? ” The failure of the banking scheme above referred to, in consequence of the limitations imposed by English law, made Adams still more decided in his assertion of the rights of American citizens, and in his opposition to Parliament. He gave up his business, in which he had little success, and became taxcollector for the city of Boston, whence he was called by his political opponents, “Samuel the publican.” In all the proceedings which issued at last in the declaration of independence Adams was a conspicuous actor. He took part in the numerous town meetings, drafted the protest which was sent up by Boston against the taxation scheme of Grenville (May 1764); and, being chosen next year a member of the general court of Massachusetts, soon became one of the leaders in debate. Upon his entry into the House he was appointed clerk, and had thus much influence in arranging the order of business and in drawing up papers. Attempts were more than once made by the English governor to win him over by the offer of a place, but Adams proved inflexible. His uncompromising resistance to the British Government continued; he was a prominent member of the continental Congress at Philadelphia, and was one of those who signed the Declaration of Independence in 1776. He was a member of the convention which settled the constitution of Massachusetts, and became president of its Senate. From 1789 to 1794 he was lieutenant-governor of the State, and governor from 1794 to 1797, retiring in the latter year partly on account of age, but partly also because the Federalists were then in the ascendant, and he himself was inclined to the Jefferson or Republican party. He died on the 3d Oct. 1803. In an oration on American independence, delivered in Philadelphia, 1st Aug. 1776, Adams characterises the English as “a nation of shopkeepers.” The oration was translated into French, and published at Paris; and it is therefore not unlikely that Napoleon’s use of this phrase was not original.
